CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, January 23, 1954, pg. 1, reads: "Marilyn Ware Brown ...misses appointment.  Portions of accompanying article read:  "An East Liberty resident has filed a complaint before the local Fair Employment Practices Commission trying to find out why she was passed over for appointment as policewoman, although she topped the Civil Service list for that post.  The young woman is Mrs. Marilyn Ware Brown, 614 Paulson Avenue, East LIberty, who came through at the top of the civil service list with a grade of 99 in the examination results posted Dec. 8.  Mrs. Brown, however was left at the post when two appointments were made recently being passed over in favor of candidates who posted lower grades..."Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 14, 1956, pg. 2, reads: "Mrs. Marilyn W. Brown...tops list - bypassed."  Portions of accompanying article by Ralph E. Koger read:  "Attention, Human Relations Commission!  What! Again?  No Job for Marilyn Brown - James F. McShane, secretary to the Civil Service Commission, said Wednesday that Mrs. Marilyn Ware Brown's name should be stricken from the Civil Service eligible list for policewoman because she has been 'undercut' (bypassed) three times...  Mrs. Marilyn Ware Brown of 614 Paulson Ave., has learned to her dismay that this is true.  For approximately three years, Mrs. Brown has been in the number on position on the eligible list for appointments to become a policewoman...   Three women who ranked below Mrs. Brown have been appointed as policewomen..."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Marilyn Ware Brown posed in domestic interior, horizontal format
